did.abstract: The Right to Decency organization was centered in Macomb County, Michigan, and was dedicated to the elimination of “the vast amount of pornography and obscenity inundating society.” The record group includes correspondence, organizational records, meeting minutes, newsletters, flyers, articles, and recordings regarding the activities and administration of the organization.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The record group was received on November 29, 2005 from the organization's founders, MaryEllen and Art Gavin (donor no. 9673).

bioghist.p: MaryEllen and Art Gavin founded Right to Decency, Inc., in 1986 at St. Malachy Parish, Sterling Heights, Michigan. The organization began when pornographic magazines, which were in full-view at the local drugstore, dismayed MaryEllen Gavin. Ellen began a dialogue between the vice-president of the drugstores' headquarters and her parish and surrounding area churches. She and her allies insisted that the store cover the magazines and get them out of view. Success ensued, when the entire chain of 80 stores, made a corporate decision to stop the sale of pornographic magazines entirely. With that success, 12 persons began to meet each month, educating themselves about the ways they could work against pornography and obscenity. They discovered existing laws, which prohibited the distribution of these materials. They began to contact the public, eventually mailing their newsletter on a quarterly basis to more than 330 Catholic churches in the archdiocese, to 50 Protestant churches and about 700 families, informing them of what could be done to curtail activities of the pornography industry.

Right to Decency was sponsored by St. Malachy parish until incorporated in 1993. The organization operated as a Resource Center, staying informed about local and national issues which related to maintaining a healthy, moral, community environment. The group educated the public by explaining their own 'success stories' in working against indecency as well as providing the expertise of other state and national decency organizations. One early resource used, was the book Final Report of the Attorney General's Commission on Pornography, published in 1986 (Introduction by Michael J. McManus). Also see the list of books and other materials, etc. distributed free of charge to the public when Right to Decency disbanded. This list is found in the "Bentley Historical Library" folder within the Correspondence series.

The group relied on Federal Communications Commission (F.C.C.) regulations when monitoring offensive dialogue and programming on radio and television. They also worked with federal, state and local government to improve existing laws and used these laws to protest illegal pornography and obscenity in movies, magazines, the Internet, at the public library and at local businesses.

Protests consisted of letter-writing campaigns, seen in the Correspondence Series containing letters to local and national politicians, to government agencies and to the local newspapers and radio programs. They also used other tactics such as boycotting, petitioning, picketing and publicity to create change.

The group was not solely about anti-obscenity issues. They advocated issues regarding traditional family values such as sexual abstinence before marriage, traditional marriage between one man and one woman, pro-life from birth until a natural death and the power of prayer. They also promoted national decency campaigns in the Southeast Michigan area such as the White Ribbon Against Pornography (W.R.A.P.), National Day of Prayer, and Turn Off TV Day campaigns.

MaryEllen and Art Gavin decided to retire after 21 years. They could not find a person(s) to lead the non-profit, volunteer organization or to manage the Right to Decency extensive website. They contacted the Detroit Archdiocese of Detroit and asked if they would take over the Right to Decency Website. The Archdiocese declined, explaining that their budget was downsized in recent years. They said they had no one to maintain the website and no one knowledgeable to answer questions from the public even if they had the funds. Interested churches and persons received much of the Right To Decency materials at no charge.

The American Decency Association in Fremont, Michigan, Morality in Media in New York, New York and the Thomas More Law Center in Ann Arbor, Michigan were the recipients of Right To Decency's remaining revenue.

The Southeast Michigan organization, Citizens for Responsible Broadcasting, (See www.responsiblebroadcasting.com/) received the "pending" Right to Decency radio complaints, which are still being investigated by the Federal Communications Commission (F.C.C.) in Washington, D.C. (M.E. Gavin, April 20, 2006)

scopecontent.p: The Right to Decency records include correspondence, organizational records, meeting minutes, newsletters, flyers, articles, and recordings regarding the activities and administration of the organization.

The Background and Administration series, 1986-2006, (0.50 linear feet) contains documents regarding the organization's founders, the goals and objectives, meeting minutes, publications, and acknowledgments.

scopecontent.p: The Activities and Projects series, 1985-2005 (0.75 linear feet) contains records pertaining to the organization's activities advocating decency and prayer, and involvement in local and national events. The most prominent event RTD was involved in was the White Ribbon Against Pornography campaign sponsored by Morality in the Media of New York. RTD publicized this annual event by distributing ribbons and printed material to all Catholic churches in the Archdiocese of Detroit (330 churches), plus about 50 Protestant churches, other organizations and many hundreds of individuals. RTD also annually mailed packets of White Ribbon campaign instructions to all churches and to persons who requested the information.

The Affiliated Groups series, 1985-2006, (.25 linear feet) contains records of the relationship between RTD and Catholic parishes and Protestant churches who were working for decency (against illegal pornography and obscenity). RTD had monthly meetings at, and was funded by, St. Malachy parish, initially reaching out to more than 200 churches. Later in 1993, when RTD received a Grant from the archdiocese of Detroit Catholic church, (Peace and Justice Commission), they increased their mailing list to include all the Catholic churches in the Detroit Archdiocese as well as 50 Protestant churches and 700 other subscribers. In 1993, RTD registered in Lansing as a corporation and moved to 'donated' office space in Roseville, MI.

scopecontent.p: The Political Figures, Agencies, and Legislation series, 1990-2004, (0.50 linear feet) includes information about RTD's interest and involvement in the local and national, political arena. Most of these records include correspondence and notes about specific legislation, government agencies, and prominent political figures.

scopecontent.p: The Correspondence series, 1985-2006, (1.0 linear feet) contains all of Right to Decency's correspondence. Letters and emails are in chronological order, and they record the organization's communication with individuals and organizations.

The Campaign for Decency series, 1985-2005, (1.0 linear feet) includes the organization's protests against various media outlets such as movies, television and radio. The organization also campaigned against sexually oriented businesses in the Southeast Michigan area. RTD was opposed to the vast proliferation of pornography, especially when in view of children (Violation of "Harmful to Minors Act" P.A. No.33 of 1978, revised since then) and distribution of obscenity (violation of P.A. No. 343 of 1984). Right to Decency was actively involved with legislators in revisions to the Michigan obscenity law (P.A. No. 343 of 1984) in 1991-2002 testifying in Lansing and at other locations. They were diligent in keeping notes, reports and clippings about these issues.

scopecontent.p: The Telephone notebook series dates from 1990 to 2006, and provides notes on Right to Decency telephone conversations. The notes summarize work completed on that day.

odd.p: (include notes on conversations and organizational activities)

scopecontent.p: The Audio and Visual series, 1997-2002, (.50 linear feet) includes VHS and cassette tapes. The tapes contain recorded meetings of the Warren City Council where RTD members spoke about sex businesses, the White Ribbon Campaign, and other community issues. Other tapes contain cable TV shows featuring the RTD Co-Founder and other RTD members, and various cassettes contain radio interviews about topics such as NYPD Blue TV and other topics about the media.
